channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2012 The New York Times Company

item.title: At Western Wall, a Divide Over Prayer Deepens
item.description: After years of legislative and legal fights, the movement for equal access for people to pray as they wish at the Western Wall has become a rallying cause for liberal Jews.
item.dc:creator: By JODI RUDOREN
item.media:credit: Rina Castelnuovo for The New York Times
item.media:description: Members of Women of the Wall prayed this month while wearing tallits, fringed prayer shawls, and tefillin, leather prayer boxes, both of which Jewish men are told to wear.

item.title: IHT Rendezvous: Adding More Bricks to the Great Firewall of China
item.description: Chinese government censors appear to have reinforced their Internet firewall in recent days, blocking some of the leading services that allow people on the mainland to access forbidden sites like Twitter, Facebook and YouTube.
item.dc:creator: By MARK MCDONALD
item.media:credit: Sim Chi Yin for The New York Times

item.title: Syrian Airstrikes Reportedly Kill Dozens at Bakery
item.description: Activists said Syrian warplanes conducted deadly airstrikes that killed dozens of people lined up for bread at a bakery in the central town of Hilfaya.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By KAREEM FAHIM

item.title: Syrian Resort Town Is Stronghold for Alawites
item.description: The resort town of Tartus is seen as a possible place for Alawites, including President Bashar al-Assad, to establish a rump state if the government falls.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By an EMPLOYEE of THE NEW YORK TIMES in SYRIA and NEIL MacFARQUHAR

item.title: India Ink: India Reacts to Tendulkar's Retirement from One-Day Cricket
item.description: Sachin Tendulkar announced his retirement from one-day cricket on Sunday.
item.dc:creator: By MALAVIKA VYAWAHARE

item.title: IHT Rendezvous: Home for the Holidays, or Not: An Expat Christmas in New York
item.description: Before my two children were born, I would always go back to France for the holidays. But fares for a family of four at Christmas are so expensive, we have to make other traditions.
item.dc:creator: By CATHERINE BRIKKÉ

item.title: As Egypt Constitution Passes, New Fights Lie Ahead
item.description: An Islamist-backed constitution was approved by voters, propelling deeply split political factions into a new phase in the battle over Egypt’s future.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK and MAYY EL SHEIKH
item.media:credit: Tara Todras-Whitehill for The New York Times
item.media:description: Egyptian women walk into a polling station. Millions went to the polls to pass judgment on an Islamist-backed constitution, whose passage represented an important milestone in Egypt’s chaotic two-year transition to democracy.

item.title: IHT Rendezvous: Strapped Spanish Put Hopes in Lottery
item.description: Spain won some relief from economic gloom on Saturday as millions checked their tickets in the annual Christmas lottery. The top prize as usual went to the government, which raised a bundle for the treasury at a time when every euro helps.
item.dc:creator: By HARVEY MORRIS
item.media:description: Schoolchildren called the top prizewinning number in Spain's Christmas lottery on Saturday.

item.title: India Ink: Protests Over Rape Turn Violent in India
item.description: Angry protests escalated into violence in India’s capital Sunday, after thousands of people gathered to demand justice for the victim of a recent gang rape in New Delhi.
item.dc:creator: By HEATHER TIMMONS, NIHARIKA MANDHANA and SRUTHI GOTTIPATI
item.media:description: Indian demonstrators in front of the India Gate monument in New Delhi overturn a police barricade during a protest calling for better safety for women, following the rape of a student last week.

item.title: Clashes Break Out in India at a Protest Over a Rape Case
item.description: Protesters in New Delhi demanded justice and better policing after the rape of a 23-year-old medical student.
item.dc:creator: By GARDINER HARRIS and HARI KUMAR
item.media:description: The police used water cannons on demonstrators gathered in India’s capital city on Saturday.

item.title: North Korean Rocket Had Military Purpose, Seoul Says
item.description: The South Korean Defense Ministry said that the North Korean rocket launch was intended to test a ballistic missile that could put the West Coast of the United States in range.
item.dc:creator: By CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: As Charter Nears Passage, Egyptians Face New Fights
item.description: An Islamist-backed constitution appeared to be headed for approval, propelling deeply split political factions into a new phase in the battle over Egypt’s future.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK and MAYY EL SHEIKH
item.media:credit: Tara Todras-Whitehill for The New York Times
item.media:description: Egyptian women walk into a polling station. Millions went to the polls to pass judgment on an Islamist-backed constitution, whose passage would represent an important milestone in Egypt’s chaotic two-year transition to democracy.

item.title: Philippines Enacts Strong Penalties for Abductions by Security Forces
item.description: The abductions, one of the ugly legacies of the country’s years of dictatorship, will be punishable by life in prison under the legislation, which was hailed by human rights activists.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: By FLOYD WHALEY

item.title: India Ink: Police Crackdown in Delhi Sunday After Protests Over Rape
item.description: Attempt to contain growing anger over attacks on women.
item.dc:creator: By THE NEW YORK TIMES

item.title: India Ink: Newswallah: Long Reads Edition
item.description: Best of long-form journalism this week.
item.dc:creator: By NIHARIKA MANDHANA

item.title: Russian Bill Worries Adoptees and Families in U.S.
item.description: Russian adoptees and their American families say an advancing bill would put children’s health and welfare at risk.
item.dc:creator: By ERIK ECKHOLM
item.media:credit: Matt Roth for The New York Times
item.media:description: Deborah McFadden adopted her daughter Tatyana, who is paralyzed from the waist down, from an orphanage in Russia.

item.title: Chess: Chess: Correspondence Champion Is Crowned
item.description: Ron Langeveld of the Netherlands won the World Correspondence Chess Championship in October, although computers have removed much of that title’s luster.
item.dc:creator: By DYLAN LOEB McCLAIN

item.title: Acting C.I.A. Director, Michael J. Morell, Criticizes ‘Zero Dark Thirty’
item.description: Michael J. Morell said the movie exaggerates the role of coercive interrogations in producing clues to the whereabouts of Osama Bin Laden.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By SCOTT SHANE

item.title: Chinese-American Faces Trial in China Over Business Dispute
item.description: Whether a defendant is a benevolent businessman or a mobster, and whether the police tortured him, is at issue.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW JACOBS
item.media:credit: Du Bin for The New York Times
item.media:description: Anna Wu, 27, dismissed the allegations that her father was a mob boss, calling him “just a regular businessman.”

item.title: Taliban Claim Role in Attack That Kills Pakistan Politician
item.description: The Pakistani Taliban claimed responsibility on Saturday for a suicide attack that killed a senior politician, one of the most high-profile assassinations in months.
item.dc:creator: By ISMAIL KHAN and SALMAN MASOOD

item.title: Taliban Hint at Softer Line in Talks With Afghan Officials
item.description: Senior figures have signaled a willingness to work in Afghanistan’s political mainstream, but getting Afghans to believe the group might abandon its brutal ways is a tall order.
item.dc:creator: By MATTHEW ROSENBERG and TAIMOOR SHAH
item.media:description: Police officers on Friday near the Hôtel Château de la Tour, north of Paris, where Afghan officials met with Taliban envoys.

item.title: Russia Says It Won’t Play Role in Ousting Syria’s Leader
item.description: Comments by Russia’s foreign minister came after recent signals that his country sees the military balance shifting in Syria, but still strongly opposes international intervention.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By ELLEN BARRY and KAREEM FAHIM
item.media:description: The mother of a rebel with the Free Syrian Army mourned as his body was brought home during his funeral in Aleppo.

item.title: Boston Priest to Lead Vatican’s Oversight of Sexual Abuse Claims
item.description: Pope Benedict XVI on Saturday named a priest from Boston, the epicenter of the sexual abuse crisis in the United States, as the Vatican’s new sex crimes prosecutor.
item.dc:creator: By LAURIE GOODSTEIN and RACHEL DONADIO

item.title: Nicolás Maduro, Chávez’s Chosen Successor, Draws Mixed Opinions
item.description: Mr. Maduro, a longtime loyalist, has all of President Hugo Chávez’s support but needs to win over the party, who often blame Mr. Chavez’s lieutenants for the government’s inefficiency and corruption.
item.dc:creator: By WILLIAM NEUMAN
item.media:description: Nicolás Maduro, named vice president of Venezuela in October, spoke this month in Caracas.

item.title: IHT Rendezvous: This Week in the Global Arts Guide
item.description: What's on view in art museums around the world.
item.dc:creator: By ELISABETH HOPKINS
item.media:description: "Joseph Recounts His Dream," a 1910 painting by Emil Nolde.
